newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan firms grew slightly cheerier in March - BOJ.
newsitem.headline: Japan firms grew slightly cheerier in March - BOJ.

text.p: Japan's major manufacturers grew slightly more positive about business conditions in March, according to a closely watched Bank of Japan (BOJ) survey released on Wednesday.
The BOJ's quarterly corporate survey, or "tankan", showed that the diffusion index for large manufacturers rose to plus two in March from minus three in the previous survey in November.
The index represents the percentage of firms expecting business to improve minus those which expect it to worsen. The higher the number, the more optimistic the outlook.

Economists, who had forecast a rise to between minus two and plus two, said, however, that the improvement in the key index would do little to prompt a tightening of interest rates. The tankan is seen as an important indicator of monetary policy.
The central bank has kept rates at historically low levels since September 1995 when the official discount rate was cut to 0.5 percent in a bid to kick the economy out of recession.

Economists said although the economy was recovering, uncertainty created by tax increases from April 1 meant the BOJ was unlikely to move toward tightening credit for the next three months at least and probably not until the first quarter of 1998.
